title: First-time investors fuel home loan surge
text:
Mr Khatak said investors with multiple properties were "essentially out of the market" because the banks are still imposing tough assessment policies.

"I have five investment properties and despite the lower assessment rates, my servicing capacity still falls short, so I'm out of market," he said.

"I'm going to be out of market unless my income goes up substantially, which I don't see happening in this environment anyway."

Rise High Financial Solutions mortgage broker Marissa Schulze said banks have been tightening the different parts of their servicing calculators, which made it harder for investors with multiple properties to qualify for a loan.

Some banks have reduced the proportion of rental income they take into account when calculating the investor's borrowing capacity from 80 per cent to 70 per cent.

"This means investors with multiple properties are already behind the eight ball on borrowing capacity compared to new investors," she said.

Newer investors are also getting mortgages through through quicker than existing investors because it's simpler to process their loan applications.

Advertisement

"Obviously the more you borrow, the more loans have and the closer the lenders will scrutinise your servicing capacity," said Mark Hewitt, an executive with ASX-listed broker AFG.

"I think for someone buying their first investment property and they already own their home, it's a simpler transaction to look at for lenders compared to someone who has multiple investment properties," Mr Hewitt said.

"The more properties you have, the higher your borrowing and this makes you a higher risk for the banks."

It's even harder for investors who already maxed out their borrowing capacity as they are unable to refinance their interest only loans, said Ms Schulze.

"Most banks now require that borrowers who want to extend or refinance their loans to go through a new set of applications, which mean new assessment rates," she said.

Investors who had reached their serviceability limit wouldn't be able to borrow more.

"Even if your financial situation hasn't changed, because the living expenses are now higher, your borrowing capacity might have weakened, which mean you can't take out a loan to buy more investment properties," Ms Schulze said.

This was leading investors to seek out finance from smaller lenders, Mr Hewitt said. The latest AFG data shows loan volumes now approaching a 50-50 split between the major and non-major banks - something unheard of as little as five years ago.

Non-major banks accounted for 45.9 per cent of mortgage written in the September quarter, the highest level since 2007, the figures show.
description: First-time property investors are behind the surge in home loan approvals, lured into the market by low interest rates and loosening credit rules particularly from smaller lenders, brokers said.
